Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: System Optimization and Data Analysis in Two-Dimensional Liquid Chromatography
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Sarah Rutan at Virginia Commonwealth University, Professor Peter Carr at University of Minnesota, Professor Dwight Stoll at Gustavus Adolphus College and their groups will address the challenges of performing quantitative comprehensive two dimensional liquid chromatography (LCxLC). This technique carries out separations of the component molecules present in complex mixtures using two very different liquid separation systems, and offers a more powerful method for separating complex mixtures such as urine. The proposed research will enable LCxLC to become a practical technique for the analysis of small molecule metabolites, which will therefore lead to more rapid and facile discovery of molecular markers of disease and treatment. The intellectual merit of the work carried out by this team of investigators lies in the development of a fundamental understanding of how changes in the chemistry of the chromatographic separation processes affect the characteristics of the resulting data, developing an understanding how these chemical factors affect the performance of the data analysis methods, and tuning the data analysis methods to adapt to these data features. These efforts will transform a time-consuming process that is at best semi-quantitative, into a rapid and efficient method that will provide precise, quantitative results for biomarker identification.

The broader impacts of the work lie in providing biological scientists with the tools needed to characterize the amounts and relationships of various molecular players as they vary depending on growth, disease state and environmental exposure. This research will contribute towards reaching a holistic understanding of complex biological systems. This knowledge will contribute to refined technologies that have tremendous promise for understanding and curing diseases, enhancing agriculture and preserving the environment. In order to make chromatographic concepts more accessible to students, a series of dynamic, online homework problems will be developed based on online LC simulators. There is also a strong component of human resources development in the training of graduate and undergraduate students, and post-doctoral scholars for careers in chemistry and biology. The students working on this project will benefit from the synergy of working with three talented and creative researchers in separation science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project (CHE-1213244) was part of a larger collaborative project with Principal Investigators Prof. Peter Carr (University of Minnesota) and Prof. Sarah Rutan (Virginia Commonwealth University). The goal of the collaborative effort was to deepen our fundamental understanding of the capabilities and limitations of the technique used in this work – two-dimensional liquid chromatography (2D-LC) – and develop new algorithms for effectively and efficiently analyzing the large volume of data produced by this technology. In working toward this goal, effort in Principal Investigator Prof. Stoll’s laboratory (Gustavus Adolphus College) was focused on the development and characterization of a new mode of 2D-LC referred to as ‘selective 2D-LC’. At Gustavus, this work provided research opportunities for six different undergraduate students. Three of these students are still enrolled at Gustavus, one has graduated and is currently enrolled in dental school, and the other two have graduated and are currently pursuing doctoral degrees in chemistry.

Effort on this project in the Stoll Laboratory has resulted in deeper fundamental understanding of selective 2D-LC, application of the technique to real-world analytical problems, and the development of a new data analysis algorithm. Much of the fundamental understanding has been focused on the challenge of transferring sample from the outlet of a first column to the inlet of a second column in a 2D-LC system. This is an important process that has a significant impact on the sensitivity of the technique and its applicability to real problems. The new understanding will inform the design and development of a new generation of instrumentation for 2D-LC with better performance. The work has also resulted in the development of 2D-LC separations for the analysis of methamphetamine and related compounds in urine, and the analysis of a class of anti-cancer compounds called furanocoumarins that are found in vegetables. Each of these analyses is difficult because of the tremendous complexity of the sample materials. A new data analysis algorithm called ‘2D Assisted Liquid Chromatography’ leverages the chemical information obtained from both dimensions of the 2D-LC system to more effectively analyze the data, whereas previous approaches mainly focused on the use of data from only one dimension of the system.

The results of work from PI Stoll's Laboratory have been disseminated widely in the form of presentations at scientific conferences (seven presentations), and in the form of research articles in high quality peer-reviewed scientific journals (three articles). As a result of this dissemination numerous researchers are applying the knowledge gained in a variety of industries and research areas including the pharmaceutical industry, the health and medical fields, forensic science, the food industry, the chemical and petroleum industries, and in life science research.
